div.head: Introduction
div.p: In September and October 2013, Chinese President Xi Jinping, during a visit to central Asia and southeast Asia countries, successively put forward the major initiative of building a "Silk Road economic belt" and "a new Maritime Silk Road of the 21st Century" (hereinafter referred to as the "Belt and Road", which is abbreviated as B&R). This has aroused great attention of international society. The B&R is not an entity or a mechanism, but the idea and proposal of cooperation and development, and effective regional cooperation platform.

More than 30 years of reform and opening up in China has accumulated huge assets. By 2013, China's external financial assets hit 5.94 trillion dollars (2013 China's balance of Payments Report), only 6604.8 billion dollars in China's outward foreign direct investment (FDI) (2013 Statistical Bulletin of China's Outward Foreign Direct Investment), accounted for about 11%. But the outward FDI of the world's average level is 30%. Expanded Chinese foreign direct investment will become the important force of Chinese economic growth and promote the growth of the world economy over the next 20 years. Of course, while producing opportunities, it also brings challenges to Chinese enterprises. Thus, when Chinese investors determine the country to be investigated, they need to analyze the present situation of the country and then assess the country's risk. How to assess the risk level of alternative countries correctly becomes a key problem.

The reality is always of great complexity and uncertainty, and the human cognition is with inevitable fuzziness. Therefore, when people are assessing the attributes of a specific object, such as the risk of an investment object, they are more inclined to using "high", "medium", "low" and other similar linguistic terms to express their assessing results [1][2]. That is to say, linguistic terms are more in line with people's thinking habits. Furthermore, affected by many factors such as decision makers (DMs)' lacking of knowledge and the complexity of decision making problems, the DMs usually cannot use precise numbers to describe their preference information. In such a situation, linguistic variables are a useful and practical form to express the DMs' judgements. Therefore, decision making based on linguistic variables deserves our attention and has become an important research direction in the field of decision analysis.

In traditional fuzzy linguistic approaches, the DMs express their preferences or assessing judgments only by one linguistic term. In practice, however, the DMs may have some hesitations on several possible linguistic terms. For example, a DM may think that it may be "very good", "good" or "a little good", but is not sure how good it is. To deal with such kind of problems, Rodriguez et al. [3] proposed the concept of hesitant fuzzy linguistic term sets (HFLTSs). HFLTSs collect possible linguistic values provided by the DMs are included and all of these terms have equal importance degree or weight. However, in some practical cases, there exist different importance degrees or weights among these possible linguistic terms. That is to say, the probabilities of the linguistic terms are not equal. For example, when comparing the risk level of two investment projects A and B , a DM gives his/her preference values using the linguistic term set  01 ,, There are five DMs who think the risk of A over B is low, two DMs who think the risk of A over B is medium, and the other DMs cannot give their preference values. To better describe such a case, Pang et al. [4] extended the HFLTSs to a more general concept, named as probabilistic linguistic term sets (PLTSs). The PLTSs allow the DMs to provide more than one linguistic term, serving as the value of a linguistic variable. This improves the flexibility and richness of the expression of linguistic information and is better for the DMs to express their linguistic evaluations or preference information. Besides, PLTSs can reflect different importance degrees or weights of all the possible evaluation values of a specific object, and thus, the research on PLTSs is necessary.
div.formula: s
div.p: When the DMs use linguistic information to express their judgements, there are many different forms, such as evaluation values of attributes, preferences. Affected by the DMs' lacking of knowledge and the complexity of decision making problems, the DMs sometimes cannot give their evaluation values of attributes directly. At this time, it is a useful way for the DMs to provide their judgements by pairwise comparisons. In the decision making problems with linguistic variables, the investigation on linguistic preference relations (LPRs) [5,6] is an important branch. As a common tool to collect preferences, the LPRs have been studied and have wide applications in decision making [7,8]. Therefore, preference relations expressed by linguistic information are worthy to study. In this paper, we focus on studying the decision making problem with probabilistic linguistic preference relations.

As an important property of LPRs, consistency has been studied by many scholars [9][10][11]. It guarantees that the DM is neither random nor illogical in his/her pairwise comparisons and helps us to get the reasonable results. Particularly, as for incomplete preference relations, how to manage the incomplete information is an important issue [1,7,10]. There are many methods to estimate the missing information, which can be roughly divided into two types: estimating the missing values by using the own preferences and estimating the missing values by using other experts' preferences.
Estimating the missing values by using the own preferences and consistency criteria is a useful way to avoid incompatibility [2]. What's more, the methods based on the consistency have been applied
extensively in real life to complete the incomplete preference relations. For example, Alonso et al.

[10] estimated the missing values in an incomplete preference relation based on the additive consistency. Wang et al. [19] developed some interactive algorithms for completing incomplete linguistic preference relations based on consistency measures. This further indicates the importance of the consistency. Thus, after the PLPR is proposed, we study its consistency. To define the consistency of LPRs, the traditional methods use transitivity, such as the additive transitivity [12].
In this paper, we also consider the consistency for PLPRs from the perspective of transitivity.

Furthermore, more and more scholars tend to deal with consistency with more intuitive methods, among which the graph theory is a very popular one. There are lots of researches using the graph theory [13] as a tool to deal with weak consistency (transitivity) [14]. However, there is little research using the graph theory to deal with additive consistency. Wang and Xu [15] demonstrated that if the weights of a digraph are well defined and used, then the additive consistency can be visually interpreted from the perspective of the graph theory. Motivated by the additive consistency based on the preference relation graph [15], we consider the additive consistency for PLPRs from the perspective of digraph.

However, the consistency definitions using transitivity are unable to estimate the consistency degree of an inconsistent linguistic preference relation, and are also unable to identify whether the consistency degree is acceptable or not [12]. To deal with this problem, Dong et al. [12] proposed the consistency index to test the consistency level of LPRs and set the range of acceptable consistency based on the probability theory. In this paper, we introduce the acceptable consistency of the PLPR after defining the consistency index of the PLPR. Then, as for the PLPR which is of unacceptable consistency, an automatic optimization method is proposed to improve the consistency until it is acceptable. This consistency improving and reaching process ensures that a DM is being neither random nor illogical in his/her preferences [12,16].

This paper is organized as follows: In Section 2, we review some basic knowledges about linguistic evaluation scales and PLTSs. Several operations of PLTSs used in the later parts are also defined. In Section 3, the concept of PLPR is firstly proposed. Then the consistency of the PLPR is discussed from the perspective of the graph theory. In Section 4, we give the consistency index to estimate the consistency degree of a PLPR. Afterwards, for the PLPR with unacceptable consistency, we propose an optimization method to improve the consistency until it is acceptable. Once all the PLPRs are of acceptable consistency, we directly use the integration operators to obtain the comprehensive preference values of alternatives and then rank the alternatives according to the derived preference values. In Section 5, an application example is given to present how to apply the consistency checking process and the consistency improving method of the PLPR to practical decision making problem. Meanwhile, we rank the alternatives by using the integration operator and then select the best one.

div.head: Consistency improving for the PLPR with acceptable consistency
div.p: In order to get a more reasonable solution, there exists an important problem to be addressed before making the final decision: a PLPR should be consistent, that is to say, as for the inconsistent PLPR, a consistency improving process is needed. Upon this issue, a lot of work has been done in the last decades, and mainly focused on the reciprocal [0,1]-valued preference relations (also called fuzzy preference relation) [21]. In this section, focusing on the probabilistic linguistic preference relations, a consistency index and a consistency improving model are introduced, and then, the whole decision making process based on PLPR is illustrated.

div.head: Application to the Belt and Road
div.p: This section presents a risk assessment example about the hot topic "Belt and Road" to illustrate the proposed method. In "China-Central Asia-West Asia economic corridor", since China advocates the "B&R" strategy, the Central and West Asian countries strengthen the investment cooperation with Chinese companies in energy, infrastructure and other fields. This brings opportunity, but also increases risk.

A Chinese company is planning to invest a country along the "China-Central Asia-West Asia economic corridor". It aims to choose a country of the lowest risk from the four alternative countries: United Arab Emirates (UAE), Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Israel. A group of experts (decision organization containing five experts) were invited to provide their preference information over the alternative countries by comparing each pair of them. Because of the complexity of the evaluation problem, the experts cannot give specific risk assessment values in crisp numbers, but in the form of linguistic terms. Furthermore, the experts may be hesitant among many linguistic terms and the experts may have different preference degrees for these countries because that the knowledge and the information of the experts are not equivalent. Therefore, using PLTSs to express preference information is reasonable and necessary.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: As a new form to express preference information, the PLTS is flexible and practical. In this paper, we have firstly proposed the probabilistic linguistic preference relation (PLPR). As a novel and visualized tool, the preference graph based on the graph theory has been used to define the consistency of the PLPR. Then, the consistency index of the PLPR has been proposed to check whether the consistency of the PLPR is acceptable or not. If the consistency of the PLPR is unacceptable, then the PLPR needs to be optimized, and thus, an optimization method has been proposed. div.head: PLTS versus HFLTS
div.p: As an extending of HFLTS, PLTS is compared with HFLTS. In this case, if the experts use the HFLTSs to express their preferences, then the preference degree (or probabilities) of the possible linguistic terms is not considered. The hesitant fuzzy linguistic preference relation is:

The HFLTS means that DMs may be hesitant among multiple linguistic terms and cannot reflect the importance degree of these linguistic terms. It can be interpreted as that all possible linguistic terms in a HFLTS have same importance degree, i.e., same possibilities. Accordingly, a HFLTS can be rewritten as a PLTS, in which all linguistic terms have same possibility.
